title: Tidyverse
text:
Sales analysis:
Some business insights for bike sellers is created in this section. Two analyses based on two important categories (year and state) have been made.
Code:

# Load libraries ----
library(tidyverse)
library(rvest)
library(stringr)
library(tibble)
library(rmarkdown)
library(readxl)
library(scales)
options(dplyr.summarise.inform = FALSE)

# Importing Files ----
suppressMessages({
bikes <- read_excel('bikes.xlsx')
bikeshops <- read_excel('bikeshops.xlsx')
orderlines <- read_excel('orderlines.xlsx')
})

# Joining Data ----
joined_data <- left_join(orderlines, bikes,
  by=c('product.id'='bike.id')) %>% left_join(bikeshops,
  by=c('customer.id'='bikeshop.id'))

# Wrangling Data ----
joined_data_wragled <- separate(joined_data, col = 'category',
  into = c('category.1', 'category.2', 'category.3')
  ,sep = ' - ')
joined_data_wragled <- joined_data_wragled %>% mutate('total_price' = price * quantity)
joined_data_wragled <- joined_data_wragled %>% select(-c(...1, gender))
joined_data_wragled <- joined_data_wragled %>% select(-ends_with('.id'))
joined_data_wragled <- bind_cols(joined_data_wragled, joined_data %>% select(order.id))
joined_data_wragled <- joined_data_wragled %>% select(order.id, contains('order'),
  contains('model'), contains('category'), price, quantity, total_price, everything())
joined_data_wragled <- joined_data_wragled %>% set_names(names(.) %>% str_replace_all('\\.', '_'))
joined_data_wragled <- joined_data_wragled %>% rename(bikeshop = name)

# analysis by state ----
joined_data_wragled <- joined_data_wragled %>% separate(col = 'location',
  into = c('city', 'state'), sep = ', ')
sales_by_state <- joined_data_wragled %>%
  group_by(state) %>%  summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
  ungroup()
sales_by_state <- sales_by_state %>% mutate('sales_text' = dollar(sales, big.mark = ',',
  prefix = '', suffix = ' €'))

# analysis by year and state ----
sales_by_year_state <- joined_data_wragled %>%
  select(order_date, total_price, state) %>%
  mutate('year' = year(order_date)) %>%
  group_by(year, state) %>% summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate('sales_text' = dollar(sales, big.mark = ',', prefix = '', suffix = ' €'))

This graph compare total revenues of different states:

  sales_by_state %>% ggplot(aes(x = state, y = sales)) + 
  geom_col(fill = "red") +
  geom_label(aes(label = sales_text)) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ',', prefix = '', suffix = ' €')) +
  labs( title = "Revenue by state",x = "", y = "Revenue") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))







This graph compare total revenues of different states in different years:

sales_by_year_state %>% ggplot(aes(x = year, y = sales, fill = state)) + 
  geom_col() +
  facet_wrap(~ state) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ',',
    prefix = '', suffix = ' €')) +
  labs( title = "Revenue by year and state", fill= 'state')

Note



A reduced data set related to patent data provided by the USPTO is analysed here.
library(tidyverse)
library(data.table)
library(vroom)
library(lubridate)

col_patent_types <- list(id = col_character(), date = col_date("%Y-%m-%d"),
                         num_claims = col_double())
col_patent_assignee_types <- list(patent_id = col_character(),
                                  assignee_id = col_character())
col_assignee_types <- list(id = col_character(), type = col_double(),
                           organization = col_character())
col_uspc_types <- list(patent_id = col_character(), mainclass_id = col_double(),
                       sequence = col_double())
patent_tbl <- vroom(file = "patent.tsv", delim = "\t", col_types  = col_patent_types, 
                    na = c("", "NA", "NULL"))
patent_assignee_tbl <- vroom(file = "patent_assignee.tsv", delim = "\t",
                     col_types  = col_patent_assignee_types, na = c("", "NA", "NULL"))
assignee_tbl <- vroom(file = "assignee.tsv", delim = "\t",
                      col_types  = col_assignee_types, na = c("", "NA", "NULL"))
uspc_tbl <- vroom(file = "uspc.tsv", delim = "\t", col_types  = col_uspc_types,
                  na = c("", "NA", "NULL"))

3 Question 3:Innovation in Tech: What is the most innovative tech sector? For the top 10 companies (worldwide) with the most patents, what are the top 5 USPTO tech main classes?
using dplyr

patent_organization_class_dplyr <- left_join(patent_organization_dplyr,uspc_tbl, relationship = "many-to-many") %>% select(1:5)

#> Joining with `by = join_by(patent_id)`

patent_organization_class_dplyr <- patent_organization_class_dplyr %>% filter(!(is.na(organization))) %>% group_by(organization) %>%
  mutate(number_of_patents = n()) %>% ungroup()
top_organization_dplyr <- patent_organization_class_dplyr %>% group_by(organization) %>% slice(1) %>% ungroup() %>%
  arrange(desc(number_of_patents)) %>% head(10) %>% pull(organization)
patent_organization_class_dplyr %>% filter(organization %in% top_organization_dplyr & !(is.na(mainclass_id))) %>%
  group_by(mainclass_id) %>% summarise(number_of_incidents = n()) %>% ungroup() %>% arrange(desc(number_of_incidents)) %>% head(5)

title: Data Visualization
text:
1 Challenge:
Time course of the cumulative Covid-19 cases!

## data manipulation for desired coutries ----
covid_cases_country <- covid_data_tbl %>%
  select(location, date, new_cases) %>%
  mutate(new_cases = replace_na(new_cases, 0))

covid_cases_country <- covid_cases_country %>%
  filter(location == "Germany" | location == "France" |location == "Spain" |
           location == "United Kingdom" |
           location == "United States") %>%
  filter(date <= '2022-04-19')

covid_cases_country <- covid_cases_country %>%
  group_by(location) %>% mutate(cum_sum = cumsum(new_cases)) %>%
  ungroup()

covid_cases_country <- covid_cases_country %>% select(1:2, 4) %>%
  set_names(c('location', 'date', 'cumulative_cases'))

## data manipulation for Europe ----
covid_cases_Europe <- covid_data_tbl %>%
  select(continent, location, date, new_cases) %>%
  mutate(new_cases = replace_na(new_cases, 0))

covid_cases_Europe <- covid_cases_Europe %>%
  filter(continent == 'Europe') %>%
  filter(date <= '2022-04-19')

options(dplyr.summarise.inform = FALSE)
covid_cases_Europe <- covid_cases_Europe %>%
  group_by(continent, date) %>% summarise(new_cases = sum(new_cases)) %>%
  ungroup()

covid_cases_Europe <- covid_cases_Europe %>% 
  mutate(cum_sum = cumsum(new_cases))

covid_cases_Europe <- covid_cases_Europe %>% select(1:2, 4) %>%
  set_names(c('location', 'date', 'cumulative_cases'))

## data combination ----
cumulative_cases <- bind_rows(covid_cases_country, covid_cases_Europe)

## ggplot ----
#cumulative_cases %>% ggplot()
cumulative_cases %>% ggplot(aes(date, cumulative_cases, color = location)) +
  geom_line() +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Spectral") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = dollar_format(scale = 1e-6,
                                            prefix = "", suffix = " M")) +
  geom_label(aes(label =  dollar(cumulative_cases, big.mark = '.',
                                 decimal.mark = ',', prefix = '', suffix = '')),
             vjust = 1, hjust = 1.3, size  = 3,
             fill  = "red",color = "white",
             data = cumulative_cases %>% slice(n())) +
  geom_label(aes(label =  dollar(cumulative_cases, big.mark = '.',
                                 decimal.mark = ',', prefix = '', suffix = '')),
             vjust = -0.2, hjust = 1.2, size  = 3,
             fill  = "blue",color = "white",
             data = cumulative_cases %>% slice(4190)) +
  labs(title = "COVID-19 confirmed cases worldwide",
       subtitle = "As of 19/04/2022",
       x = "", y = "Cumulative Cases",
       color = "Continent / Country") +
  theme_light() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom", 
        plot.title = element_text(face = 'bold')) +
  theme(axis.title = element_text(face = "bold")) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1, size = 6)) +
  scale_x_date(date_breaks = "1 month", date_labels = "%B %y") +
  expand_limits(x = c(as.Date('2020-01-01', format = "%Y-%m-%d"),
                      as.Date('2022-04-01', format = "%Y-%m-%d")))

title: Data Visualization
text:
2 Challenge:
Visualization of the distribution of the mortality rate.

## data manipulation ----
world <- map_data("world") 

mortality_rate <- covid_data_tbl %>% filter(date <= '2022-04-16') %>%
  select(continent, location, new_deaths, population) %>%
  mutate(new_deaths = replace_na(new_deaths, 0)) %>% filter(!(is.na(continent))) %>%
  select(2:4)
total_death <- round(sum(mortality_rate$new_deaths) / 1e6, digits = 1)
deaths_ratio <- mortality_rate %>% group_by(location) %>%
  reframe(deaths_per_population = sum(new_deaths) / population) %>%
  group_by(location) %>% slice(1) %>% ungroup() %>%
  set_names(c('country', 'deaths_per_population')) %>%
  as.data.frame
deaths_ratio['deaths_per_population'][deaths_ratio['deaths_per_population'] == 0] <- NA
deaths_ratio['country'][deaths_ratio['country'] == 'United Kingdom'] <- 'UK'
deaths_ratio['country'][deaths_ratio['country'] == 'United States'] <- 'USA'
deaths_ratio['country'][deaths_ratio['country'] == 'Democratic Republic of Congo'] <-
  'Democratic Republic of the Congo'

combined_data <- merge(world, deaths_ratio, by.x = "region", by.y = "country", all.x = TRUE)

## ggplot ----
suppressWarnings(ggplot() + geom_map(data = combined_data, map = world, color = 'white',
         aes(x = long, y = lat, map_id = region, fill = deaths_per_population)) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "red", high = "black", na.value = 'gray',
                      labels = scales::label_percent()) +
  theme_void() + 
  labs(title = "Confirmed COVID-19 deaths relative to the size of the population",
       subtitle =  str_glue("Around {total_death} Million confirmed COVID-19 deaths worldwid"),
       caption = "Date 04/16/22",
       x = '', y = '',
       fill = "Mortality Rate") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = NULL) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = NULL))
